name: Independence National Historical Park
description: The park represents the founding ideals of the nation, and preserves national and international symbols of freedom and democracy, including Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell. The Declaration of Independence and US Constitution were both debated and signed inside Independence Hall, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
shortDescription: The park represents the founding ideals of the nation, and preserves national and international symbols of freedom and democracy, including Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell. The Declaration of I...

operatingHours.description: Independence National Historical Park operates daily from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm.  Hours of operation for certain historical buildings and facilities change seasonally throughout the year.  Most of the park grounds are open 24 hours a day to pedestrians.  All buildings are closed on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day. Please see the park's website for hours of operation.  http://www.nps.gov/inde/planyourvisit/hours.htm

fees.title: Timed Entry Reservation - Location
fees.description: Entrance to Independence Hall requires a guided tour. Tickets are required.

climate.weatherDescription: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.

images.title: The Liberty Bell
images.altText: Color photo of the Liberty Bell with Independence Hall in the background.
images.caption: Recognizable for its crack, the Liberty Bell remains significant today for its message of liberty.

images.title: Independence Visitor Center
images.altText: A color photo of the Independence Visitor Center showing a brick building with tall windows.
images.caption: Plan your visit, use the restrooms, and take advantage of the free WiFi  in the Independence Visitor Center.

images.title: Independence Hall
images.altText: Color photo of Independence Hall as seen from the north side of Chestnut Street.
images.caption: Known as the birthplace of the United States, Independence Hall houses the room where the Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution were both signed.

images.title: The Assembly Room in Independence Hall
images.altText: A color photo of the Assembly Room showing 18th century chairs and green, cloth covered tables
images.caption: The Assembly Room in Independence Hall is where the Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution were both signed.

images.title: The Benjamin Franklin Museum
images.altText: A color photo of the exterior of the Benjamin Franklin Museum in Franklin Court.
images.caption: Explore Franklin's life and character in the Benjamin Franklin Museum. The museum features artifacts, computer animations, and interactive displays that are geared toward visitors of all ages.

images.title: The Franklin Court Printing Office
images.altText: A color photo of a printing press in the Franklin Court Printing Office.
images.caption: Franklin's printing office no longer survives, but it would have had equipment similar to what you'll see in the Franklin Court Printing Office.

images.title: Portrait Gallery in the Second Bank of the United States
images.altText: The exterior of the Second Bank of the United States showing a marble building with eight columns.
images.caption: The Second Bank of the United States houses a fine collection of over 100 portraits, many of them by 18th century artist Charles Willson Peale.
